alternatives.transcript: this presentation summarizes our program to develop a new device and procedure for lung cancer screening by breath analysis the program Personnel include researchers and clinicians at quadrivium the University of California at San Diego Medical Center Argonne National Laboratory Texas A&M Health Science Center New Star lasers
the UCLA Center for Health Sciences and hark dr. Clifton Mountain our principal clinical investigator will now present clinical and biological information on lung cancer

I'm dr. Clifton Mountain I'm professor of surgery in the division of cardiothoracic surgery at the University of California in San Diego I've spent over 35 years of my professional life in the the study of then diagnosis of lung cancer of staging of lung cancer and of surgical therapy
the American Cancer Society as estimated one hundred and seventy one thousand new cases of cancer in the coming year with 160,000 deaths

the incidence of lung cancer in the male population has leveled off and is thought to be decreasing but in the female population the number of new cases of lung cancer is actually increasing and it is now the most important and largest cause of cancer deaths in females far surpassing of breast cancer at the present time

this disease is a worldwide problem lung cancer is seen for example in this graphic display of the incidents and death rates in males and females in the lower columns for Western and Eastern Europe the United States is about number 15 in the worldwide incidence of the disease
there are estimated by the American Cancer Society over 1 million lung cancer deaths worldwide for the 1998

lung cancer is so deadly in part because it is usually detected too late to prevent its spread to other parts of the body which we term metastasis in our own study of 5230 cases completed at the MD Anderson Hospital in tumor Institute we found that the five-year survival rate of lung cancer patients depended strongly upon the stage in which the disease was detected
and treated and stage 1A treatment when the disease was highly localized The Five-Year survival rate was greater than 60%
in later stage treatments The Five-Year survival rate declined markedly so that overall the average five-year survival rate in this population was only 20%
in National figures it is generally cited as 13 to 15 percent

ideally we would like to detect lung cancer and an even earlier than stage 1A when it is a colony a small colony of malignant cells which we would term carcinoma in situ and there would be no obvious symptoms of the disease at this stage

you have lung cancer could be detected and treated as carcinoma in situ emerging treatment modalities such as anti-angiogenesis drugs the retinoids which have been shown to reverse the process of in situ carcinoma to normal and photodynamic therapy might be highly effective resulting in five year survival rates that could be as high as 90 or
to understand how very early stage lung cancer may be detected
we can examine some aspects of clinical biology beginning with carcinoma in situ a colony of malignant bronchial epithelial cells that is highly localized

malignant cells are known to have different Metabolism from normal cells for example malignant cells use anaerobic glycolysis as a significant metabolic pathway whereas normal cells use oxidative phosphorylation almost exclusively
these two a metabolic pathways both generate Trace Amounts of volatile organic compounds or vocs in addition to their main metabolic products of carbon dioxide and water

the types and amounts of vocs are different for the two Pathways so there are characteristic the o.c. biomarkers that are produced by malignant cells in the carcinoma when it is in an insight to Stage as the cancer progresses through micro Invasion stromal Invasion and further growth of the tumor with vascularization other metabolic
like products

resulting for example from enzymatic dissolution of the epithelial basement membrane and the underlying stroma are produced which may present other biomarkers characteristic of the stage of lung cancer

since many of these metabolic products in the form of these vocs are excreted in our breath we believe that a non-intrusive or non-invasive and sensitive lung cancer screening tests can be achieved by performing breath analysis more recently there have been studies of breath analysis but using a gas chromatography and Mass spectrometry

these methods however although they provide some very tantalizing data about differences in metabolic and products between normal tissue and lung cancer they nevertheless are not useful or applicable in this terms of screening however we do have a new laser detection methodology which should prove a very Optical as a screening technique

I'm Michael Berry the principal investigator of our program to develop a new method for lung cancer screening and detection I'm working with dr. Clifton mountain and other clinicians and Pathologists in California together with Rick Menefee and Joe Valderrama here in Texas to use a technique called laser photoacoustic detection for ultra-sensitive breath analysis

laser focus like detection is literally using a laser to hear molecules being excited it's capable of analyzing the trace volatile organic compounds in human breath that are present at only a level of one to a few hundred billions of the amount of normal are

let me show you how a laser photo Coos tick detection experiment works first the patient's breath is collected in a small bag that can be mailed to a laboratory for analysis and this bag has a feature of allowing us to discard a lot of the Dead Space are from from our mouths and air passages and collect only the alveolar air from our

lungs in order to get a true sample of the volatile organic compounds from our lungs so you'll see as I blow into this that first the discard bag expands and after it's filled a little one way valve is tripped open and the main collection bag collects an air sample

Nom Nom the breathing mouthpiece can be removed and this little baggie packed and sent to the laboratory for analysis when it arrives in the laboratory the sample from this small bag can be transferred into a photoacoustic sample cell which is inserted within the cavity of a tuna
double Laser Source

and detection by a sensitive microphone on the photoacoustic cell is performed using electronics and computer control to capture and process the signals produced by the laser photo Cusack detector spectrometer

in the LPD process modulated laser light is absorbed by molecules in the sample cell these excited molecules then collide with other molecules in the cell transferring part of their internal excitation into translational energy that is into heating of the gas mixture the resulting temperature increase produces a pressure increase in other words an acoustic wave which is detected by a sensitive hearing aid microphone

this process of detecting direct absorption of energy by molecules is ultra-sensitive and permits us to detect the volatile organic compounds in human breath since each volatile organic compound has a characteristic absorption Spectrum LPD using a tunable Laser Source allows us to detect absorption differences in breath Spectra that are related to concentration differences
has of the volatile Organics produced by metabolic differences of malignant compared to normal lung epithelial cells
breath analysis has been performed for over 200 years however the difficulty of collecting and rapidly analyzing breath samples has prevented widespread clinical use

previous breath analyses have demonstrated that breath contains over 400 Trace endogenous volatile organic compounds and that there are statistically significant differences in these volatile organic compound concentrations for some diseases such as diabetes
due to metabolic abnormalities diabetics have increased breath acetone levels compared to non diabetics
important to our own program a previous breath analysis study using gas chromatographic separation and mass spectrometric detection that's abbreviated gcms analysis

on breath volatile organic compounds established that lung cancer patients have significantly different concentrations of acetone to butanone and other vocs compared to matched control subjects the gcms technique however is too expensive and time-consuming to form the basis of a lung cancer screening test

by analogy with practical screening tests that are used clinically we believe that a lung cancer screening tests based on LP d-- has the potential to be inexpensive and routinely useful only small breath samples are needed and these can be analyzed without separation and our concentration steps in addition LPD can be computer automated to perform Ultra sensitive detection of breath Spectra quickly

simply hey important and indeed essential part of our program is the conduct of clinical trials to validate the technology the pilot study is designed as a proof of principle that the LPD breath spectral analysis can distinguish between lung cancer patients and control subjects

in this pilot work 12 lung cancer patients having been diagnosed with stage 3 a or 3 B disease will be enrolled together with two groups of 12 each control subjects that are matched in terms of Agents sex with the patient's one control group will include non-smokers while the other control group will include heavy smokers with no known pulmonary
these in this context heavy smokers are defined as smokers with a 30 pack year or more history

all the subjects will receive the same clinical assessments including matched breath sample collection and Analysis although the lung cancer patients will be subjects with relatively late stage disease this pilot study will be very useful to find characteristic spectral signatures which will be more abundant in the later stage disease because of the greater mass of malignant tissue

the pilot studies has already been improved approved by the institutional Review Board of the University of California in San Diego and it has been reviewed by the FDA subject recruitment has already begun

for the second clinical study which is a retrospective study designed to provide a preliminary determination of the sensitivity and specificity of the lung cancer screening test a group of 120 cancer patients with diagnosed stage 1 or stage 2 disease will be recruited

in addition 120 matched subjects in each of a number of control groups such as a group of non-smokers heavy smokers with no known pulmonary disease subjects with pulmonary disease other than lung cancer and subjects with Cancers other than lung cancer will be recruited

all of the subjects will receive the same clinical assessments again including matched breath sample collection and Analysis ideally any screening test should have a high Sensitivity I heed a positive identification of all or most of the patients with lung cancer equivalent to a low percentage of false negatives as well as a high specificity that is little or no
or no identifications of false positive cases
now a third study will be a prospective clinical trial
it will be a study completed on high-risk subjects who have no symptoms of lung cancer

if the lung cancer screening test is successful in identifying early stage disease with a high sensitivity and in not identifying false positives it will be broadly useful for a general population we anticipate having at least 1,200 Iris subjects with the clinical assessment as previously described

by analogy with American Cancer Society recommendations for prostate and breast cancer screening we may anticipate that the American Cancer Society will recommend an annual lung cancer screening test for all men and women over age 50 and four young men and women at high risk the LPD clinical studies involving human patients just described by dr. Clifton Mountain

form the heart of our program to develop a new lung cancer screening test however other supplementary studies will also be very useful in allowing us to establish that we can use the test for the earliest stage screening namely for detection of carcinoma in situ

in particular we plan to perform a cell culture study using laser photo kusich detection of volatile organic compounds produced by Adeno carcinoma squamous cell carcinoma and other types of lung cancer cells these isolated cell cultures resemble carcinoma in situ the earliest stage of cancer in patients if we can find and treat lung cancer in the carcinoma in situ stage patients
it's may have a five-year survival rates of 90% or better we also plan to perform a new type of mass spectrometric detection
called Soft ionization Mass spectrometry

which will help us to identify which volatile organic compounds are actually responsible for the lung cancer biomarkers let me say a few words about the budget for the overall study it can be broken down into four parts the pilot clinical study which is already in progress and will be completed by the end of November

the much larger retrospective clinical study on patients we are anticipating enrolling 120 patients that are stage 1 lung cancer patients 120 patients that are stage 2 and 120 controls of each of four groups in order to complete this study which will be the first presented to the FDA in order to
develop our screening test

this is the largest most expensive parts of the overall program but then the supplementary studies that I described to you namely the cell culture study and the soft ionization Mass spectrometry study will be extremely valuable to identify early stage carcinoma in situ and to identify the specific volatile organic compounds that are the biomarkers produced by malignant cells
we're very excited about the potentiality of developing a broadly useful lung cancer screening tests and we heartily endorse your participation and sponsorship of our program
